author: Karl Gernetzky
title: Universities suspend classes, postpone exams as fee protests continue | Education
text:
DEMANDS: Wits university students protest outside the Parktown campus over fee hikes on Tuesday. Vice-chancellor Adam Habib has opted to forego his bonus and donate the proceeds to students. Picture: PUXLEY MAKGATHO Related articles Nene says no new funds will be allocated for higher education in 2015 Skills levy could be used to fund students, says Treasury official Related multimedia Students storm gates of Parliament in ‘fees must fall’ protest against budget In this article People: Blade Nzimande THE University of the Witwatersrand (Wits), the University of Cape Town, Rhodes University, University of Pretoria, University of the Free State and University of Limpopo were among the institutions that suspended classes and postponed exams on Wednesday.
Stellenbosch University, which saw extensive protests, along with the University of Johannesburg and University of KwaZulu-Natal on Wednesday remained open — but with indications on social media from student leaders at those institutions that protests were planned for Thursday.
The South African Student Congress had vowed to shut down all institutions in a "national day of action" earlier this week in demand of "0% fee increases".
Operating under the #NationalShutDown, students at 15 universities aimed to co-ordinate protests in demand of a freeze on university tuition.
At Nelson Mandela Metropolitan University a meeting between the university’s vice-chancellor, Derrick Swartz, and students is scheduled for Thursday at the institution’s sports stadium. On Wednesday, police fired rubber bullets and teargas to disperse students who blocked two key entrances to the institution’s campus.
A similar meeting between management and student leaders is scheduled at the Tshwane University of Technology, which likewise saw protests at some campuses.
The Democratic Alliance Students Organisation (Daso) said on Wednesday it would picket outside the Department of Higher Education and Training’s headquarters in Pretoria.
Daso will demand the removal of Higher Education Minister Blade Nzimande, while the broader position of the DA is that student protests should refocus on the lack of state financial support for universities.
National Shutdown Collective member Anele Nzimande said on Wednesday the grouping of organisations — which co-ordinated on the demands but remained open and nebulous — was demanding that the Department of Higher Education and Training respond by Friday to co-ordinated demands. The demands include an announcement of a fee decrease percentage for 2016 and a move towards free tertiary education.
There were continuing attempts to co-ordinate with students at Technical Vocational Education and Training colleges and agricultural colleges but this was difficult, said Ms Nzimande.
Media coverage had focused on formerly white institutions, which itself was reflective of structural problems, and the movement aimed to be as inclusive as possible, she said.
With RDM Newswire
